Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor W. Carl Lineberger of the University of Colorado, together with his postdoctoral and graduate student researchers, will study the transient structures and reactive processes involving reaction intermediates and solvated anions. The experimental techniques include time-resolved photodissociation and photoelectron imaging spectroscopy and negative-ion photoelectron spectroscopy. Important classes of molecular systems that will be investigated include three-member cyclic carbon-nitrogen radicals important in combustion, the OO-OH radical important in determining the atmospheric concentration of OH near the tropopause, and a variety of ion-neutral complexes important in understanding proton transfer. A key component of all of the proposed experiments is the extensive participation of theoretical collaborators that brings state of the art theory, simulation, and experiment together.

While the systems to be investigated have been chosen for their fundamental science implications, they often have important medium-term applications, in fields ranging from atmospheric chemistry to combustion science to anionic polymerization. This project will also be a vehicle for scientific workforce development by providing students and postdoctoral researchers with a solid foundation across many areas of chemistry. In addition, participants in this research program will make important contributions to the extension of the Colorado Science Education Initiative (SEI) to undergraduate physical chemistry classes at Colorado. Finally, both the research and educational activities described in this proposal provide an essential credibility for the principal investigator in his continuing activities that involve advocacy of research and education for the physical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A generic chemical reaction can be considered to be an encounter between two “reactant” molecules, A and B, that might result in forming two new “product” molecules, C and D, where in this process chemical bonds have been broken, new bonds have been formed, and the shapes and properties of the new product molecules may be very different from those of the reactants. As one “views” this chemical reaction process evolving, there may come a “point of no return” on this reaction pathway, where further progress must lead to the formation of the new product molecules. This transient, key configuration in the reaction is called the “transition state.” Understanding the structure and properties of this transition state is key to understanding and possibly controlling the nature of products of chemical reactions. In a Colorado analogy, the transition state can be viewed as something akin to a mountain pass, with the reactants on one side of the pass, and the products on the other. Journeying via the pass is the easiest way to get from one side to the other, and when you are at the pass there exists the greatest range of outcome opportunities with a slight nudge in any of a number of directions. For this reason, this short-lived, very elusive transition state has been the object of intense investigation by experimental and theoretical chemists for a number of years. Even with all of this activity, there remains a major scientific impetus to better understand how to study transition states and how to manipulate them in order to gain better control over chemistry.

This research project, supported by the National Science Foundation, utilizes isolated negative ions (a molecule with an extra electron attached, giving a net negative charge) interacting with a laser beam to investigate the properties of transition states and the role of a surrounding solvent in mediating a chemical reaction. Specifically, we have investigated the ozone negative ion (O3-) partially solvated by water or the inert gas argon to better understand the possible role of the solvent in controlling the chemistry of photoexcited O3-. This particular negative ion was selected for study because it has been implicated as a possible route for the formation of the smallest aggregates in the atmosphere that might lead to aerosol formation. The use of the inert argon solvent both cools the complex and affords the possibility of trapping complexes in metastable configurations along the reaction coordinate. While this study has not answered this question definitively, it does provide significant new insight into reactions of ions when surrounded by solvents. During this grant period, related experiments have been carried out on other difficult to observe free radicals that are important to physical organic chemistry or possibly biological processes.

            While the molecular complexes that were investigated were primarily chosen for their fundamental additions to science, they often have important medium-term applications in fields ranging from atmospheric chemistry to combustion science to anionic polymerization. As an important consequence, this project makes a substantial contribution to the training of the scientific workforce by providing students and postdoctoral researchers with a solid foundation across many areas of chemistry. Together with the development of sophisticated experimental skills and a broad appreciation of the methodology, both experimental and theoretical, they learn to address complex issues and obtain definitive results. Most important, they complete professional training both required for a successful career in science, as well as a passion for practicing science. Over the period of this award, support has been provided for one undergraduate student, six Graduate students, and three Postdoctoral Associates. Of these 10 individuals, four now hold faculty positions in universities, three are employed in industry or a national laboratory, one is currently a Postdoctoral Associate, and two are graduate students nearing completion of their PhD work.
